content: Potential issue: The wording of this puzzle assumes or forces the solver to imagine that they are a boy.
If there aren't any objections, I'd like to add cover art to this puzzle.

Maybe it's just my algo, but n = 1 and n = 2 are edge cases for me which I must separately calculate. So I had a hard time debugging my failure in the 1st validator. Maybe add a test case with n = 1? Thank you :)

Made a few changes to wording and formatting.

Renamed test cases and validators to be more consistent (e.g. toilet instead of toilets).

Moved the "1-indexed" explanation and "smallest index" requirement from the output description to within the puzzle statement (below the rules) where I believe fit better.

Swapped first test and validator to help dummies such as myself who can't read the output section properly and put the requested values in the right order.

And approved.

For clarification, although this problem is in the same topic as (https://www.codingame.com/ide/47157008f1572734caa27079fd80c3215af76b7), this is significantly harder than the other problem, since:
1. The other problem just finds the next position, which is very simple, while this problem finds the maximum number of people that can use the toilet based on the starting position
2. The naive solution to this problem, which is simulating the process for each starting position, will take very long time to complete. With [[n]] as large as 1500000, a smarter solution needs to be devised.
The issue is that it dumps a rule from https://blog.xkcd.com/2009/09/02/urinal-protocol-vulnerability/ : "the basic premise is that the first guy picks an end urinal" ^^
It is specified that n>=2, so there is no need to handle n=1. Previously the first test was n=2, and the validator n=3, but JBM below swapped it.
